nodes.label:
Pesticides
maximise
yield
nodes.desc: Utilitarian argument: increasing yield justifies the use of chemical inputs. Rooted in a short-term productive efficiency ethics.

nodes.label:
Pesticides
destroy
biodiversity
nodes.desc: Empirical and ethical argument: pesticides reduce species diversity, irreversibly damaging the ecosystem. Intrinsic value of non-human life.

nodes.label:
Biodiversity
has intrinsic
value
nodes.desc: Fundamental ethical principle (deep ecology): species have value independent of their utility to humans. Basis of biocentric environmental ethics.

nodes.label:
Profitability
justifies
chemical inputs
nodes.desc: Anthropocentric and economic argument: economic efficiency takes precedence over ecological considerations. A short-sighted view of value.

nodes.label:
Long-term
soil health
comes first
nodes.desc: Sustainability argument: preserving soil structure and microbial life is a necessary condition for any future agriculture. Ethics of responsibility.

nodes.label:
Composting
fertilises
naturally
nodes.desc: Practical and ecological solution: compost maintains fertility without degrading the ecosystem, supported by soil science. Convergent argument between efficiency and ethics.

nodes.label:
Eco-gardening
is too
demanding
nodes.desc: Practical objection: the time and skills required by ecological practices represent a real barrier for most amateur gardeners.

nodes.label:
Native plants
support the
ecosystem
nodes.desc: Ecosystem argument: native plant species provide habitat and food for local fauna, reinforcing trophic networks. Functional and intrinsic value.

nodes.label:
Killing pests
protects
crops
nodes.desc: Instrumental justification: pest insects cause economic losses, legitimising their elimination. Ignores the moral value of invertebrates.

nodes.label:
Insects have
moral
value
nodes.desc: Ethics of care extended to invertebrates: even insects, capable of feeling, deserve moral consideration. Sentientist or biocentric approach.

nodes.label:
Intensive
irrigation
wastes water
nodes.desc: Empirical argument: excessive watering depletes groundwater and contributes to regional water stress, particularly in the context of climate change.

nodes.label:
Rainwater
harvesting is
accessible
nodes.desc: Pragmatic counter-measure: simple, low-cost solutions (tanks, mulching) make it possible to reconcile gardening with water resource conservation.

nodes.label:
Chemical
fertilisers
are effective
nodes.desc: Immediate efficiency argument: synthetic fertilisers provide rapidly assimilable nutrients, optimising short-term growth.

nodes.label:
Chemical
fertilisers
degrade soil
nodes.desc: Empirical and ethical rebuttal: acidification, salinisation and destruction of microfauna are documented long-term effects of chemical fertilisers.

nodes.label:
Future generations
have a right to
healthy ecosystems
nodes.desc: Intergenerational justice (Rawls, Jonas): we have a moral obligation to pass on a viable environment. Principle of responsibility towards the future.

nodes.label:
Pollinators
are ecologically
indispensable
nodes.desc: Functional and ethical argument: bees and other pollinators ensure the reproduction of 80% of flowering plants. Their decline directly threatens food security.

nodes.label:
Preserving
water is a
moral duty
nodes.desc: Water is a threatened global common good. Its preservation is a matter of global ethical responsibility â€” towards living and yet-to-be-born humans, and towards other species.
